awd_titl_txt: CI-ADDO-NEW: MobiLab -- A Global-Scale Live Laboratory to Support Mobile Computing Science
awd_abstract_narration:
The importance of mobile computing is rapidly increasing but the field is held back from its potential by the difficulty of evaluating new ideas. The effectiveness of mobile computing systems depends on variable network, application, and user behaviors, many of which are only visible in large-scale systems.  To enable transformative research on mobile computing and related disciplines, this project creates a global-scale live laboratory composed of mobile devices, networks, and their users that will support the validation of research ideas.  This live laboratory, referred to as MobiLab, makes two key contributions: (1) it provides an online repository of real-time and archived mobile user data, including vital information such as location-specific network conditions, per-application energy usage, and user behavior and (2) through a set of software libraries and tools, it simplifies the tasks of developing, deploying and evaluating research applications. Instead of re-building applications to monitor network, application, mobile system, and user behavior, researchers can gather information online from MobiLab tools via easy-to-use application programming interfaces (APIs). The target communities include researchers in several disciplines, such as mobile systems and networks, embedded systems, network security, mobile data privacy, and social networking. 
MobiLab is suitable for both undergraduate lab-intensive introductory courses as well as graduate-level courses that expose students to mobile computing, distributed computer system design, and distributed sensing.  MobiLab will also have a lasting impact on the research community by providing a central repository for mobile system research data, software artifacts created by the community, and results based on the data.

por.por_cntn:
The main useful outcome of this project is collection of software-based tools and data that enable mobile computing research, along the following three dimensions.  The released software and data set are available at the project web site: http://mobilab.eecs.umich.edu/

1. Mobile system platform support: We developed tools for real-time characterization of the execution environment including network conditions and energy/power use. These tools served as middleware for researchers to build prototypes to investigate ideas in mobile system and application design. In particular, energy usage characterization is one of the key contributions in set of tools created.

2. Mobile system resource and computation management: We provided middleware mechanisms and runtime policies to enable efficient sharing management and sharing of computation, communication, and sensing resources in mobile systems. In particular, mobile cloud computation and network offloading is the one of the main software infrastructure provided to bridge mobile computing with cloud computing.

3. Mobile user data repository: We built and provide access to a real-time database of (anonymized) mobile user behavior, network activity, and platform information. This enables trace-driven simulation studies and the design of mobile network systems that use such real-time information for network diagnosis or mobile application adaptation.

Along the process of creating these tools and data sets, we identified the following important lessons that can have impact on future mobile computing.

1. Network resources if not properly managed can seriously impact battery life times of mobile devices.  Important tradeoffs between performance and energy efficiency must be considered.

2. The current mobile OS design is not suitable for seamless mobile cloud computing.  Improved abstractions are needed to support offloading of both computation and network operations.

3. Mobile data contain sensitive information and must be properly anonymized to ensure privacy guarantees of users.

The proposed infrastructure has been used for both undergraduate lab-intensive introductory courses as well as graduate-level courses that expose students to mobile computing, distributed computer system design, and distributed sensing. MobiLab provided a central repository for mobile system research data, software artifacts created by the community, and results based on the data. MobiLab has also helped lighten the steep learning curve in mobile computing and engaged more researchers in this field.
